codelist.label: Borehole Purpose
codelist.definition: Purposes for which a borehole was drilled.
codelist.description: EXAMPLE: mineral exploration, water pumping, site evaluation, stratigraphic research, etc.

extensibility.label: Extensible with values at any level

value.label: geological survey
value.definition: General examination of an area's geological entities.

value.label: exploration and exploitation of raw material
value.definition: The discovery and identification of mineral resources, including the assessment of their importance and the evaluation of their economic potential.

value.label: exploration and exploitation of energy resources
value.definition: Examination of the subsurface with regard to the availability of fossil energy resources and planning the extraction thereof.

value.label: hydrocarbon production
value.definition: Production of petroleum oil and/or gas.

parent.label: exploration and exploitation of raw material

value.label: hydrocarbon exploration
value.definition: Exploration in an unproved area to test for a new field, a new pay, a deeper reservoir, or a shallower reservoir.

parent.label: exploration and exploitation of raw material

value.label: hydrocarbon appraisal
value.definition: Assessment of characteristics of a proven hydrocarbon accumulation.

parent.label: exploration and exploitation of raw material

value.label: geothermal energy, geothermal heat exchangers
value.definition: Exploration pertaining to the utilization of geothermal energy resources and design of geothermal heat pumps.

parent.label: exploration and exploitation of raw material

value.label: heat storage
value.definition: Well to enable the underground to be used for heat storage.

value.label: mineral exploration and extraction
value.definition: Well drilled for the purpose of locating and/or extracting mineral resources from the subsurface, usually through the injection and/or extraction of mineral bearing fluids.

parent.label: exploration and exploitation of raw material

value.label: exploration and exploitation of nonmetallic mineral deposits
value.definition: Prospecting with regard to the availability and planning for excavation of nonmetallic mineral deposits, mainly for construction purposes, building stones, cement and ceramic or glass industry.

parent.label: exploration and exploitation of raw material

value.label: disposal
value.definition: A well, often a depleted oil or gas well, into which waste fluids can be injected for safe disposal.

value.label: exploration of natural underground storage space
value.definition: Examination of the subsurface's ability to store various materials.

value.label: water supply
value.definition: Water supply in general.

value.label: drinking water supply
value.definition: Well construction for drinking water.

value.label: industrial water supply
value.definition: Well construction for industrial water supply.

value.label: aquaculture
value.definition: To supply water to aquaculture purposes.

value.label: irrigation
value.definition: Well construction for irrigation purposes.

value.label: emergency water supply
value.definition: Well construction for emergency water supply.

value.label: contingency water supply
value.definition: Stand-by water supply in case of water deficiency.

value.label: geophysical survey
value.definition: Examination of the subsurface's geophysical properties.

value.label: shot hole
value.definition: In connection with seismic surveys explosives are loaded into shot holes.

value.label: flowing shot
value.definition: A flowing shot hole is a drilled hole for seismic purposes that has entered an underground water source that has sufficient pressure to cause the hole to "overflow".

value.label: hydrogeological survey, water management
value.definition: Examination of groundwater flow, the chemical properties of ground water, and transport of particles, solutes, and energy, as well as the management of the sustainable use of ground water resources.

value.label: geotechnical survey, construction site characterization
value.definition: Geotechnical investigations performed to obtain information on the physical and mechanical properties of soil and rock around a site to design earthworks and foundations for proposed structures and for repair of distress to earthworks and structures caused by subsurface conditions.

value.label: geochemical survey, analyses
value.definition: Examination of chemical properties of the rock formation and /or the porosity fluids.

value.label: pedological survey
value.definition: Investigation to characterize types of soils.

value.label: environmental monitoring
value.definition: Groundwater chemistry and groundwater level is monitored.

value.label: pollution monitoring
value.definition: Monitoring of known pollution sites.

value.label: water quality monitoring
value.definition: Monitoring to assess the nature and distribution of pollutants and contaminants in groundwater; the nature and distribution of naturally occurring chemical constituents; subsurface hydrologic conditions, and hydraulic properties of strata as they relate to pollutant and contaminant movement.

value.label: groundwater level monitoring
value.definition: Construction of a gauge for recording groundwater level changes.

value.label: dewatering
value.definition: Dewatering is the removal of water from solid material or soil by wet classification, centrifugation, filtration, or similar solid-liquid separation processes. Removing or draining water from a riverbed, construction site, caisson, or mine shaft, by pumping or evaporation.

value.label: mitigation
value.definition: Lowering of the groundwater level to prevent the groundwater table to reach polluted sites.

value.label: remediation
value.definition: Remediation in general. The removal of pollution or contaminants from groundwater, soil and other rock

value.label: sparging, thermal cleaning
value.definition: A kind of remediation. In situ cleaning of soil using heat, steam.

value.label: recharge
value.definition: (a) Aquifer Recharge Wells: Used to recharge depleted aquifers by injecting water from a variety of sources such as lakes, streams, domestic wastewater treatment plants, other aquifers, etc. (b) Saline Water Intrusion Barrier Wells: Used to inject water into fresh water aquifers to prevent intrusion of salt water into fresh water aquifers. (c) Subsidence Control Wells: Used to inject fluids into a non-oil or gas-producing zone to reduce or eliminate subsidence associated with overdraft of fresh water.
